comments.text:
I don't get what's going on with these charts, it's the same with GN test results with their powercolor hellhound. My XFX MERC ultra 7900xt gets a solid 110-120fps @1440p, cinematic settings, max raytracing, FSR 2 high in Black Myth Wukong. It runs it no problem whatsoever, easily one of the most flawless running games in my library. It's paired with a 7800x3d on a MSI MPG B650 mobo with 32gb crucial 6000mhz CL36 but I don't have EXPO enabled so it's only running at 5200mhz. Can anyone explain how I'm getting almost 100fps higher than these charts? They even have RT on medium with 66% upscaling. I just don't get it lol In hellblade 2 I can get solid 80-90fps with maxed out settings with the MERC, it runs flawlessly. In both, not a stutter, not a flicker, my latency is even at like 3-5ms.

The only game I am having any issues with getting the settings just right is RDR2 which is surprising because even fully maxed out, it's demanding a little over 6700mbp/s of the cards memory, a bit over 1/4 of the total VRAM. I would think that it could handle that easily and it really actually does, in game in runs perfectly fine. But I get flickering at the game start screen and in the loading screens, can't figure out what exactly is causing that. I was having some issues with laggy menu's but if I set my refresh rate at 165 or 200hz down from 240, navigating around the menus is smooth as butter. (Vsync is on) Such weird little things cause such strange problems with PC gaming.
comments.author: @tulpasconstructor2711

Sure, there are limits, but I am thinking every other generation, so three generations, as in current (new), then back two. It's also a bit of favoritism for Nvidia going back the three generations, but not for AMD. You may not have intended it, but it's mindshare. It's psychology. It places an importance on the value most presented. In this case Nvidia. The point isn't the current topic is a new Nvidia product, the point is hierarchy and perceived importance. Let's be balanced. Not all of us are fanbois of (insert company/product here).

comments.text:
my first card (i bought) was the sapphire 6950 HD, way back then, 2011? then a second one for Crossfire couple years later. then i got an R580 couple years after that. then the 5700xt. I always wanted to get a top tier card, so i worked my ass off since 2018. winter 2024 i built my dream pc, just missing the GPU. I was finally going to afford the best, the 5090. 2k, a big stretch, was hoping for 1.5k, but id be able to do it. Then, i cant get one. Then, i lower expectations. 5080; failed. no way im paying anything over 1k for that card, that's the only value its good at, after you overclock it.
Finally ill compromise and shoot for a 9070xt.
What a miserable launch for someone who finally was going to do what he'd been dreaming and grinding for for years. I mean not that was my only focus, but I climbed my way out of 14k of credit card debt, 550 credit score, to owning a home, 800+ credit score, and over 2xing my income; and for some reason i cant describe why this stupid "top tier" was such a big deal to me. Its like, wanting the car you always wanted, finally having the means to do so, but right then it's hit such asinine pricing when you can actually make it work, and then, it just doesnt work any more. First world problems. But damn, i really thought by the time i was ready, the gpu market would actually launch decent when i could hop on board.

comments.text: I run an RTX 3070 still, and probably will continue with this card for a while. I play generally 1440P med-high settings and get around 100 fps depending on game. Like beamng, I can get 100 fps or so in 1440p. In UE5 games ive found that it lets you use DLSS and FSR FG together on some games. So in remenant 2 1440P medium using DLSS quality and FSR FG I can get 140 fps or so and the input lag isn't bad at all(No noticeable difference from native). Considering 3070's are now down to around $250 or so second hand, they are honestly still a good buy. The card does awesome in davinci resolve and I've never once had a game disappoint in 1440P. 8GB is truly still enough, if your willing to turn down settings. This card wont do 4K max natively at over 60 fps. But it will play 1440P with some still very pretty settings and a little upscaling, at a very good frame rate. I'm an FPS over looks guy, so as long as I'm at medium I'm very happy. The 3070 still gives a great gaming experience.

comments.text: Went from a 2700x/1080ti 256-bit bus 11gb that I got on release day for $699 in 2017 and then about a year ago built a completely new PC and went with the only 7800x3d they had on the shelf paired with a Radeon 7900xt 320-bit bus 20GB ($650 with tax but I added 2 years of accidental warranty for $79).  Even my 1gb HD6580 had a 256-bit bus so downgrading to 192bit bus 4070ti or 5070 with 12gb is wild.  I play on a 3440x1440 ultrawide ASUS TUF @ 180mhz HDR10 and undervolted my card with a slight overclock and I get amazing performance for the money.  The card also handles Ray Tracing pretty well.  I will always stick to AMD cards from now on even though my 1080ti still runs everything like a champ even after years of use but I know people that paid over $1000 for a 1080ti and I just got lucky because I waited at the store maybe 3 hours before it opened and the line was so long that most people didn't even get a card on release day and only a few people got them at MSRP.

comments.text: What's really fascinating about the 50 series is how little memory bandwidth seems to have mattered in the end. I wonder if it even had an effect at all considering how small the margins are, all other things being equaled. In theory, this is a huge increase in memory bandwidth compared to prior gen or the 9000 series, but no one even seems to give a shit, lol. Maybe AMD was vindicated in sticking with the older RAM to save the dollas. And on the flipside, it is worth noting that NVIDIA probably did spend a bit of chink to get that new RAM in there, and it's probably constraining the amount of it they can stow in each card while keeping the costs within ballpark. On the flip side, it appears that more RAM of older design appears to trump less of the new GDDR7 with smoking fast bandwidth speeds, at least up to a certain point. I'd certainly rather have 32 GB of DDR4 over 16 GB of DDR5.

comments.text:
Nvidia would do things differently if no one bought their GPUs. The issue is that no one cares about the consequences of buying into a closed software model with proprietary everything. No one cares how Nvidia will do things to undermine the performance of competitive cards via said proprietary software, instead of making more competitive products.

You can't blame the market when people willing bought into this, and continue to do so. 

Also: how are you going to force companies into making GPUs for our computers. Doing so requires very specialized knowledge, skillsets, and production facilities. That doesn't even begin to touch on distribution channels, advertising, etc... you can't regulate away problems to protect people from themselves. How about we take personal reaponsibility and put a little more effort into being conscious, educated consumers

For example in games like CS2 you have anti-lag 2 that seems comparable in testing to reflex 1. These latency reducing technologies can't go below the minimum latency dictated by your framerate. comments.text:
@icy1007 Bus Rate is never irrelevant nor will it ever be. The 5090 has a 512-bit bus rate. A High memory bandwidth is indicative of High performance. This concept has not changed over the course of 20 years. Those who think bus rate does not matter have no clue how it actually works!!  Here is a refresher A "512 bit bus rate" refers to a data transfer rate across a bus that is 512 bits wide, meaning it can transfer 512 bits of data simultaneously, which is typically used in high-performance graphics cards to achieve very high memory bandwidth; the exact speed depends on the clock speed of the bus, but a 512 bit bus generally indicates a very high data transfer rate. 

The 1080ti, 2070, 2070ti, 2080, 3080, 3090, 3090ti and 4070ti, 4080, 4090 5070ti, 5080 and 5090 all have a 256-bit to 512-bit bus rate. All the cards below the bus rate threshold of 256bit has been deemed trash by almost every GPU reviewer and consumer.

Again the previous 10, 20 and 30 series cards were all 256-bit bus transfer rates to start and went up to 320-bit and 384-bit. We did not have this type of consumer gripe with those cards. In fact they were actually good launches

Look at it this way!!! You would not put 192-bits of RAM in your computer and run it, it will run like dog shit. add more RAM and the system smooths out.  This concept is the same in GPU's across the board. No High end GPU came lower then a 256-bit, 320-bit, 384-bit and now the 5090 has a 512-bit bus rates!! 5090 is the New Supreme leader and will be for a awhile!!

comments.text:
Answer: Potential Directions for (AMD and Nvidia's) Evolution:

Hybrid Architectures: Combining the strengths of data center and visualization GPUs into a single chip. (A100 and A200 aspects into visualization GPU)

This could involve integrating more robust double-precision capabilities into visualization GPUs or adding specialized graphics pipelines to data center GPUs.


NPU Orchestrating - Hybrid Parallelization: Intelligent management and coordination of CPU, GPU, and NPU resources for optimal performance.

Dynamic workload distribution across specialized processing units.

Maximizing efficiency in AI-accelerated rendering and quantum-inspired applications.

Advanced I/O and Data Handling:Direct Storage-to-GPU: Standardizing APIs and hardware for direct data transfer, minimizing CPU overhead. (PS5's custom I/O's example, to surpass)

Hardware Decompression: Implementing efficient, standardized hardware decompression for faster data loading.

Smart Data Pre-fetching: AI-driven predictive pre-fetching, adaptive adjustments, and user controls.

Dynamic GANs: Utilizing generative adversarial networks for procedural content generation, adaptive LOD, and texture super-resolution.

System level optimization: Unified memory architecture, and OS/Driver optimization.

PCIe Optimization: Maximizing PCIe utilization through advanced DMA, and other techniques.

A GPU designed from the ground up to accelerate GAN training and inference. A GAN-optimized GPU would significantly reduce the time required to train complex GAN models.

AI-Accelerated Rendering: Leveraging AI to improve rendering efficiency, reduce noise, and generate more realistic images. (being done with 5000s, De-noising)

This could involve using AI to denoise ray-traced images, generate textures, or even create entire scenes. (once again, already being done in 5000s)

Quantum-Inspired Capabilities: Integrating hardware or software support for quantum-inspired algorithms (in a Classical setting), enabling new types of simulations and visualizations.

Enhanced ray tracing capabilities. (Already done, that was the 5000s)


Advanced Memory Technologies:Exploring new memory technologies that offer higher bandwidth and lower latency, such as HBM3 or beyond.

Computational memory.

Improved Power Efficiency:As power consumption becomes an increasing concern, developing more power-efficient GPU architectures is crucial.

Software and API Improvements:More open and flexible APIs that allow developers to take full advantage of the GPU's capabilities.

Better integration with AI/ML frameworks.


This expanded list now includes the vital I/O and data handling improvements, providing a more complete picture of the potential future of GPU technology.

Performance isn't everything, it is also a question of how you use the performance available. Most video games on the market today has really BAD performance and optimization.

comments.text:
@JuiceDraticZ I had a 3070ti, and if you are playing at 4K with a 3070ti, you are playing on medium settings max, with everything like MSAA on low or off, otherwise you won't even get above 40 fps in big titles.
I've been building pc's for over 20 years, and the 3070ti is not a full blown 4K card, it's a decent 1440p card, with games a few years old running at ultra settings msaa etc on high or very high, but even on recent titles the 3070ti can't pull out high fps numbers if you crank the settings up.
Games like The Last of Us consistently pulls over 10GB of VRAM on 1440p ultra settings without DLSS.
So for midern 1440p Ultra settings, without DLSS, so as Native as possible, which I prefer instead of upscaling shit, does require more than 10GB of VRAM,  even 12 is low in that case.
